This report was prepared by Chul Ju Kim, Operations Coordination Division,

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the second and third Ministerial Conferences on Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation (CAREC) held in November 2003 in Tashkent, Uzbekistan; and in November 2004 
in Astana, Kazakhstan, respectively, the ministers of the seven CAREC countries—Azerbaijan, 
the People's Republic of China (PRC), Mongolia, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, 
and Uzbekistan—reiterated their strong commitment to regional economic cooperation as a 
means to realizing a shared vision of a region where people live in harmony and prosperity, with 
free movement of goods, people, and ideas. The ministers also acknowledged a multitude of 
problems and challenges that require even greater cooperation if CAREC countries are to 
successfully integrate with world markets and achieve sustained economic growth and poverty 
reduction.  In  this  context,  the  ministers  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to 
continue to support the CAREC program by strengthening the role of the overall institutional 
framework  (OIF),1  identifying  feasible  regional  projects,  continuing  to  mobilize  or  provide 
financial resources, and further enhancing donor coordination and cooperation with neighboring 
countries. The regional technical assistance (TA) is included in the CAREC Member Countries 
Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program 2005–2007 (RCSP). The TA framework is in 
Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ADB's CAREC program began modestly in 1997 with poverty reduction as its goal. The 
CAREC program has strategically focused on improving infrastructure and policy environments 
in  the  priority  areas  of  transport,  trade  facilitation,  and  energy  to  (i)  lessen  the  region's 
geographic disadvantages, (ii) promote trade and transit within and beyond the region, and (iii) 
enhance the efficient and sustainable use of vital natural resources such as energy and water. 
The program has followed a practical and results-oriented operational approach, achieving 
tangible progress toward longer-term strategic objectives. This strategic focus and operational 
approach has been strongly supported by CAREC countries as reflected in the joint statements 
of the ministerial conferences in 2003 and 2004. 
 
3.  Much has been accomplished under the CAREC program. Five investment and program 
projects in priority sectors totaling $224.1 million are being implemented with cofinancing of 
$135.2 million from other donors. A substantial amount of grant assistance in priority areas 
amounting to $14.8 million has been provided for policy support, analytical studies, and capacity 
building. The OIF, established in 2002 to guide the CAREC program, has proven effective in 
planning, coordinating, and implementing the regional cooperation projects and activities. In 
May  2003,  several  multilateral  institutions—the  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and 
Development (EBRD), the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the Islamic Development Bank 
(IsDB), the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the World Bank—joined the 
framework to closely coordinate their support for regional cooperation under the aegis of the 
CAREC with ADB serving as the secretariat. These steps highlight the fact that the CAREC 
program has developed into a fully-fledged regional cooperation mechanism with ownership on 
the part of member countries and effective coordination among development partners. 
 
                                                
1  The overall institutional framework consists of an annual ministerial conference, senior officials meetings, sector 
committees, and project-specific working groups. 
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet edition) on 30 July 2004.

2     
4.  The progress made under the CAREC program is partly attributable to neutral and open 
exchange of ideas it creates through its meetings, forums, and working groups for CAREC 
countries and multilateral institutions. These meetings have built trust and mutual respect. 
Lessons  learned  from  ADB's  experience  in  supporting  regional  cooperation  include  the 
following: (i) strong and sustained political will continues to be important because regional 
cooperation  is  a  long-term  process;  (ii)  consensus  among  member  countries  should  be  a 
working  principle  in  promoting  the  regional  cooperation  agenda;  (iii)  strong  support  from 
stakeholders  on  regional  cooperation  is  important;  and  (v)  continued  support  for  capacity 
building at the national and regional levels remains critical for successful regional cooperation.                         
 
5.  At the ministerial conferences in November 2003 and in November 2004, ministers 
noted with satisfaction the progress made to date under the CAREC program and at the same 
time, recognized formidable challenges to advancing regional cooperation. These challenges 
include (i) reducing economic distance for restoring the region’s historical role as a land bridge; 
(ii)  increasing  trade  and  integration  with  large  markets,  both  globally  and  in  the  region’s 
proximity; (iii) improving supplies of energy and other resources; and (iv) in the longer term, 
tackling potentially negative externalities such as environmental degradation and the spread of 
communicable diseases. The ministers therefore agreed to continue progress made under the 
CAREC program by (i) strengthening the OIF; (ii) further supporting key regional projects; (iii) 
closely coordinating and cooperating with development partners, other regional initiatives, and 
private sectors; and (iv) exploring cooperation prospects with neighboring countries beyond 
current members. The CAREC member countries have requested ADB to continue to provide 
necessary support. 
 
6.  Keeping in mind the lessons learned from previous experiences for regional cooperation 
and CAREC ministers' request for support, ADB as the catalyst for the CAREC program should 
be in a position to deliver timely, carefully targeted support for the program. At the same time, 
the support should be also clearly aligned with the strategic thrusts of the RCSP. First, to 
deepen political will and trust as a foundation for cooperation, and to enhance strategic and 
implementation  aspects  of  the  CAREC  program,  OIF  components  such  as  the  ministerial 
conferences, senior officers’ meetings, sector committees, and national focal points will have to 
be  substantially  strengthened.  Given  the  ever-increasing  need  for  institutional  support  for 
important  regional  issues,  this  should  be  addressed  as  a  matter  of  priority.  Furthermore, 
strategic cooperation with important regional organizations such as Central Asia Cooperation 
Organization (CACO) and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) needs to be explored 
and synergies exploited. 
 
7.  Second,  CAREC  needs  to  focus  more  on  identifying,  preparing,  and  implementing 
feasible regional projects in priority sectors that would show tangible benefits and serve as 
champions and catalysts for further cooperation. In doing so, it will be useful to expand projects 
to include larger neighbors, thus ensuring better access to larger markets and more secure 
supplies of natural resources. Because scarce financial resources have emerged as a binding 
constraint to building and maintaining infrastructure, consultations with multilateral and bilateral 
development partners—as well as with private sectors, both internal and external—to mobilize 
financing for regional projects should be further strengthened.            
 
8.  Third,  the  CAREC  program  should  endeavor  to  build  a  conducive  environment  for 
regional cooperation in general, and for the program in particular. The relative lack of such an 
environment explains in part why regional cooperation has not reached its potential despite 
commitment from leaders and indigenous efforts by governments. Efforts are ongoing in this

3 
regard, and they include capacity building for regional cooperation3 and information exchange 
through the CAREC web site. The cooperative environment needs to further strengthened by (i) 
building  constituencies  among  the  business  community,  the  academic  community,  and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs) to support regional cooperation by providing diverse 
perspectives and peer pressures; (ii) further information-sharing and dissemination on positive 
outcomes  of  regional  projects  and  events;  and  (iii)  in-depth  analytical  studies  on  regional 
cooperation that quantify specific costs and benefits and provide regional poverty data. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The purpose of the TA is to strengthen the CAREC program in line with the strategic 
thrusts of the RCSP for CAREC countries. The main outputs and outcomes envisaged from the 
TA are (i) forums for continued dialogue among member countries and multilateral institutions 
under the CAREC mechanism; (ii) sector road maps and new regional projects, particularly in 
priority areas of transport, energy, trade facilitation and trade policy; (iii) analytical studies on 
regional cooperation; (iv) strong and effective constituencies for regional cooperation; and (v) 
expanded networks for information exchange and dissemination.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  As an umbrella TA for the CAREC program, the TA will support activities to be guided by 
the ministerial conferences under the OIF. Close consultation will be conducted with the senior 
officials’  meetings,  national  focal  points,  sector  coordinating  committees,  and  multilateral 
institutions coordination group throughout TA implementation. Specifically, the TA will support 
the activities described below. 
 
11.  Enhancing an Environment for Dialogue for Regional Cooperation. Building on the 
lessons learned from previous TAs, the TA will continue to create and support an environment 
for open and frank dialogue on regional cooperation issues as a means to building mutual trust 
and understanding. The TA will prepare the CAREC ministerial conferences, senior officials’ 
meetings,  meetings  of  sector  coordinating  committees4  and  working  groups,  and  other 
preparatory meetings under the OIF. These meetings will be more closely linked to the strategic 
thrusts identified in the joint ministerial statements and RCSP in close consultation with the 
respective national focal points and line ministries. The TA will also support close coordination 
with other development partners and regional organizations to ensure complementarities and 
synergy in support of regional cooperation. 
 
12.  Identifying Windows of Opportunity for Regional Cooperation. The TA will support 
efforts to prepare and implement sector road maps and new regional projects, particularly in the 
priority sectors of transport, energy, trade facilitation, and trade policy. Regional projects that 
engage larger neighbors will be explored in close collaboration with the ongoing TA5 to yield 
enhanced results. Possible projects include transport corridors that connect Russia and the 
PRC to warm-water ports in the Arabian Sea through the CARs, and hydrocarbon energy 
pipelines from the CARs to neighboring energy-deficit countries. Given the continuing financing

13.  Undertaking Analytical Studies. Quality economic sector work is essential in seizing 
opportunities  for  regional  cooperation.  Analysis  would  reduce  uncertainty  about  costs  and 
benefits, thus enhancing the willingness of the countries to cooperate. In this context, the TA 
supports the following analytical work: (i) a study on the strategic direction of the CAREC 
program  in  a  changing  environment,  focusing  on  coordination  and  cooperation  with  other 
regional initiatives such as CACO, SCO, and Central and South Asia Transport and Trade 
Forum; (ii) a regional database on income and nonincome poverty indicators as a foundation for 
collaborative regional efforts of poverty reduction; and (iii) further economic and sector work in 
priority  areas  in  coordination  with  ongoing  studies  on  trade,  transport,  and  transit,6  as 
appropriate. 
 
14.  Building Strong Constituencies for Regional Cooperation. As a first step toward 
building strong constituencies for regional cooperation, the TA will support organizing a regional 
business roundtable, as requested by member countries.7 Private sectors will play a larger role 
in driving regional cooperation, domestically and regionally, and thus the roundtable will provide 
a  valuable  opportunity  to  shape  the  regional  cooperation  agenda  and  offer  a  feedback 
mechanism for determining its effectiveness and impact. Given the relatively low degree of 
private-sector development in the region, the roundtable will be organized on a pilot basis in 
conjunction with other events such as the CAREC ministerial conferences and/or senior officials’ 
meetings.  Close  coordination  and  cooperation  with  existing  initiatives  in  this  area,  with 
institutions that have expertise, and with ADB's South Asia Department will be necessary to 
ensure the success of the event. The possibility of holding forums on regional cooperation for 
academics and/or NGOs will be also explored as appropriate. 
 
15.  Furthering Information Dissemination. This component aims to generate a greater 
awareness to the CAREC program and regional activities and to facilitate information exchange 
and dissemination among stakeholders. In close cooperation with ADB’s Office of External 
Relations,  the  TA  will  significantly  improve  current  CAREC  web  site  in  terms  of  its  style, 
contents, coverage, and translation into Russian. The TA will also facilitate the preparation and 
wide circulation of the quarterly regional newsletter. New methods of disseminating information 
about the CAREC program, such as publications and articles, will be also explored. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1 million equivalent. ADB will finance $900,000 equivalent 
on a grant basis by ADB's TA funding program. The participating governments will provide 
remaining $100,000, equal to the imputed value of staff time and use of government facilities 
conducting activities under the TA. Detailed cost estimates are given in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements     
17.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. ADB’s CAREC unit will be responsible for 
overall  guidance  and  implementation  of  TA  activities.  The  national  focal  points  under  the 
CAREC mechanism will continue to coordinate regional activities in each member country

5 
throughout the TA. TA activities will be closely coordinated with those of other multilateral 
institutions and regional organizations that are concerned with regional cooperation, as well as 
with ADB resident missions in the region, to ensure effective implementation. 
  
18.  TA implementation will require 7 person-months of international consulting services and 
76 person-months of domestic consulting. A core group of consultants will provide advisory, 
technical,  and  administrative  support  services  to  assist  in  the  overall  management  of  the 
CAREC  program.  In  addition  to  the  core  group  of  consultants,  consultants  for  regional 
cooperation,  private-sector  development,  and  media  and  publication  affairs  shall  also  be 
engaged. All consultants will be selected as individuals in accordance with the Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. An outline of the terms of 
reference for consultants is in Appendix 4. 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 18 months, from 1 January 2005 to 30 June 
2006. Conference and meeting proceedings, as well as studies and reports, will be published 
and posted on the updated CAREC web site and quarterly regional newsletters as appropriate. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis for 
the Greater Silk Road Initiative 2005, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  A total of 7 person-months of international and 76 person-months of domestic consulting 
services will be required under the proposed technical assistance (TA). Given that the TA will 
support a range of activities of the Greater Silk Road Initiative under the CAREC program, some 
of which are still being planned, detailed terms of reference for specific tasks may be revised 
and supplemented at a later stage as appropriate. 
 
B.  Core Group Consultants 
1.  Advisor: Regional Cooperation Specialist (5 person-months) 
2.  An internationally recruited consultant will be engaged as advisor to 
   
(i)  help coordinate, integrate, and monitor the various activities under the TA; 
(ii)  assist the head of Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Unit (CARECU) 
in planning, preparing for, and implementing conferences and meetings for the 
initiative, including the preparation of resource papers; 
(iii)  provide  support  for  identifying  and  preparing  new  regional  projects  covering 
participating and neighboring countries;  
(iv)  provide support to promote private-sector participation in the CAREC program, 
including a regional business roundtable; 
(v)  provide  support  to  promote  participation  of  other  stakeholders  such  as 
academics and NGOs; 
(vi)  oversee improvements to the CAREC web site and regional newsletter, and 
provide necessary input; 
(vii)  perform analytical studies on regional cooperation particularly in priority sectors 
of transport, energy, and trade facilitation as required; 
(viii)  participate  in  consultation  with  participating  governments  and  development 
partners, as required, on particular issues related to the CAREC program;   
(ix)  help identify and assess possible areas of focus in the CAREC program; and 
(x)  provide other technical, administrative, and coordinating support to the overall 
institutional framework (OIF) of the CAREC program, as required. 
 
2.  Development Economist (18 person-months) 
3.  A domestically recruited consultant will be engaged as a development economist to 
 
(i)  assist the secretariat to the OIF; 
(ii)  assist in organizing ministerial conferences, senior officials’ meetings, and other 
meetings  and  workshops;  prepare  resource  papers  for  these  meetings;  and 
perform other follow up activities; 
(iii)  prepare quarterly monitoring reports on TA implementation, which covers status 
of proposed activities under the TA and related activities, and outstanding issues 
and slippages for the attention of the head of CARECU; 
(iv)  maintain and upgrade a database of relevant indicators for the CAREC program, 
which  covers  (a)  implementation  status  of  regional  projects,  (b)  activities  of

12  Appendix 3 
various regional initiatives, and (c) publications and analytical studies on regional 
cooperation; 
(v)  help prepare project profiles for regional projects; and 
(vi)  help implement the TA, including (a) the monitoring of budget disbursements, 
consultant recruitment, and contract variations; and (b) the procurement of other 
inputs. 
 
3.  In-Country Regional Cooperation Specialists (48 person-months) 
4.  One domestically recruited specialist in each participating country will be engaged to 
serve as an expert with the following primary responsibilities: 
 
(i)  be the "national focal point" on regional economic cooperation, coordinating with 
other national focal points, ADB secretariat in headquarters, and the resident 
mission;  
(ii)  establish and maintain, through regular, day-to-day contact and consultation, 
long-term working relationships with key government agencies responsible for 
regional economic cooperation; 
(iii)  ensure the implementation of the regional work program in the country; 
(iv)  help identify and develop potential new areas of the initiative; 
(v)  monitor programs and initiatives of the Government and regional organizations 
on regional economic cooperation; identify, evaluate, and recommend potential 
areas for ADB assistance; 
(vi)  monitor programs of other stakeholders, especially of external funding agencies 
operating in the country; identify, evaluate, and recommend potential areas of 
cooperation; 
(vii)  participate in relevant ADB missions; 
(viii)  report on all activities monthly; and 
(ix)  perform other ADB-related tasks as assigned by the resident representative, 
when  time  allows  and  provided  that  work  relating  to  regional  economic 
cooperation is given priority. 
 
C.  Short-Term Experts 
1.  Regional Cooperation Expert (2 person-months) 
5.  The internationally recruited specialist will be engaged to undertake a study on the 
strategic direction of the CAREC program focusing on coordination and cooperation with other 
regional  cooperation  initiatives.  The  study  will  be  designed  to  provide  possible  strategic 
directions and recommended actions in a practical and sequential manner for the CAREC 
program. In particular, the consultant is required to  
 
(i)  analyze  ADB  initiatives  for  regional  cooperation,  focusing  on  possible  areas  of 
complementarities,  overlap,  and  their  implications  on  the  capacities  of  member 
countries  in  view  of  membership,  mandate,  organizational  structure,  planned 
activities, and donor alliance; 
(ii)  based on the analysis, develop specific recommendations on how to integrate such 
efforts and coordinate within ADB to avoid overlap; 
(iii)  analyze succinctly the major regional organizations in terms of their membership 
structure, strategic thrusts, core activities, financing mechanisms, donor involvement, 
strengths  vs.  weaknesses,  future  prospects,  and  effectiveness.  Major  regional

Appendix 3  13 
organizations to be analyzed should focus on, but not limited to, the Central Asia 
Cooperation Organization (CACO) and Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO); 
(iv)  develop  practical  options  for  (a)  strategic  cooperation  modality  with  these 
organizations, (b) institutional and operational adjustments of the CAREC program 
including membership, and (iii) cooperation with neighboring countries; and. 
(v)  develop concrete ways to strengthen donor partnership under the CAREC program.  
 
2.  Media and Publication Expert (6 person-months)  
6.  The domestically recruited consultant will be engaged as a media and publication expert 
to (i) improve the CAREC web site significantly; (ii) support publishing of a quarterly regional 
newsletter; (iii) prepare publications and reports related to high-profile CAREC meetings and 
events; and (iv) help arrange for media coverage of high-profile CAREC meetings, projects, and 
activities, as required. 
 
3.  Poverty Expert (4 person-months) 
7.  A  regional  database  on  income  and  nonincome  poverty  would  benefit  all  regional 
cooperation projects and activities, and has been included in the RSCP as an activity to be 
supported by this umbrella TA. A domestically recruited consultant will be engaged as a poverty 
expert to (i) review and analyze existing data on income and nonincome poverty in the region; 
(ii) build on a regional poverty database in coordination with ongoing studies on transport, trade, 
and transit; (iii) provide inputs on regional poverty for various CAREC papers; and (iv) perform 
other tasks as required.
